To allow incremental updates (add/delete) individual parameters and annotations, we need an API change. This may be best done as part of the "v2" of the API; we can treat parameters and annotations as subresources of the action as in `/api/v2/actions/ns/pkg/name/parameters`.

OK.  We have flake8 running under Python 3.  The first run is under the travis `before_script` twisty runs with the --zero-exit option so it treats _everything_ as warnings.  That run currently finds 59 style related issues.  The second run is in the travis `script` section and halts the build on Python syntax errors.

Ready for review.
I put this into #2015

Update on our status for moving to Python 3...  We have decided to go big bang (direct from Python 2.7.12 to 3.6.0) which makes it harder but we are still making progress.  The checklist (in rough order of execution) now looks like this:
- [x] #2015 Fixes those Python files that the flake8 linter missed because their filenames do not end in .py  This also implements flake8 tests that halt the build on Python syntax errors (*ready for review*)
- [x] #1867 _Closed 11 of 13_ failing tests when running under Python 3
- [x] #2020 Is a minimal change attempt to highlight the [two remaining failing tests](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2020#issuecomment-286433578).  ~**Help needed here.**~  If we can get that one to pass all tests then we can go back to the original #1903 
- [ ] #1903 Our go live on Python 3 PR

Others Python (non-blocking) issues I am still monitoring include: #1940 and #1510

It should be possible to configure Travis to push the docker images for controller, invoker, and runtimes to dockerhub openwhisk.

The push should happen only from master branch, and using Travis credentials to store the dockerhub credentials.

The only thing to be careful is not going over the 50 max time for a travis build.

Yes, `swift3runner.py` should also be updated.  As it stands, it will never get anything back from the `swiftbuildandlink.sh` script in the subprocess because it's not passing stdout/stderr into the Popen constructor.  So `o` and `e` will always be `None`.

```
p = subprocess.Popen(BUILD_PROCESS, cwd=DEST_SCRIPT_DIR)
(o, e) = p.communicate()
```

I'm not sure how this affects the test cases though, as the subprocess is used for the build step.  It should probably print the output of the script, regardless.

Let me get the tests running locally, then I'll update this PR.

On "Select containers properly", is it intended to be possible to select containers that are have in-flight activation(s)? e.g. if there is a web action defined, currently there is a single request per container handling afaict. So concurrently invoking APIs in a blocking fashion is severely limited, based on number of containers allowed.
Sounds like an issue with pg build - open in blue?

A single container may end up servicing more than one request. At any given time a container is serving at most one request. But that same container may be reused to run the same action again in the future. It is also true that more than one container may be running servicing multiple requests for the same action. This is called a warm start, and exists in the current container pool implementation as well.

I added commits for proxy configuration.

Actually, it was working with all the tests in `testLean`.
But once I rebase the code to the latest master, it does not work.

I could fix that also, but before that I pushed the commits.
I am not quite sure the way I developed, so I want to have the same view with other people first.

Once we reach a consensus about how to address this issue, I will resolve all other test failures also.
I expect lots of comments.

What I intended is as follow:

1. Setting up proxy configuration in `gradle.properties`

```
$ cat ~/.gradle/gradle.properties
systemProp.http.proxyHost=localhost
systemProp.http.proxyPort=3128
```

Then, we can run tests transparently with Docker for Mac.
```
./gradlew :tests:testLean
```

Proxy configuration is only required when running OW with Docker for Mac.
In linux, we can use it as usual.

2. Tests traffic will be sent to targets via proxy server.
So we need to run one more proxy container.

```
docker run --name squid -d --publish 3128:3128 sameersbn/squid:3.3.8-23
```
This is now resolved by using Web Actions https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2010
PG4 69, approved for first commit.

With this changes, CI for `docker for mac` is highly required.
When I rebase the code to the latest master, I noticed that newly added tests are designed in a way that proxy is not taken account.

If we decided to keep supporting `docker for mac`, all the new tests should be designed with proxy configuration.
(I think, mostly this could be done by using AkkaHttpUtils in this pr)
Makes sense to me to have one supported mac platform (docker for mac).
PG4 71 approved.

One more proposal is, how about hiding `docker-machine` guide from `ansible/README.md`?
After merging this pr, multiple guides for `docker for mac` and `docker-machine` will make users confused.

Since `docker for mac` is more natural way to use docker on OSX, I think it will be better to expose `docker for mac` guide only in `ansible/README.md`, though we keep the guide for `docker-machine` also.

A description of the process of building Docker images using Travis can be found at https://sebest.github.io/post/using-travis-ci-to-build-docker-images/
@markusthoemmes Sure - I added #2026

This would be a radical departure from the current model and comes with some significant baggage. I'll add to the list of complications:

* what does guaranteeing a CPU share mean if multiple instances of an action are running concurrently in the same container?
* similarly how do any of the limits now apply with respect to memory, io, network, diskspace?
* how do you save the user from themselves when their code is racy, or uses the file system incorrectly, what does it mean for debugging, or performance isolation?

If someone were to try - it's certainly doable (the very first whisk prototypes did this) - I can't yet imagine how it would be deployed in a production environment. I can imagine how with some program analysis, it's possible to identify actions for which intra-container concurrency may be plausible. The annotation is the early escape clause to "release" the platform from undefined, or unintended behavior. 

The serveless promise is that the platform scales to handle any given load. Before going down this road to increase density, might it be more prudent to explore leaner isolation technologies instead?

@mdeuser, when creating or updating an action, the `--web` flag adds annotations to the corresponding action. Essentially `--web` is a shortcut so that users do not have to type `-a web-export true -a final true` during action create/update. When `--web` is not specified, annotations are not modified automatically by the CLI. In contrast, `--no-web` automatically sets `-a web-export false -a final false`. The other flags, `--raw` and `--no-raw`, do the same as the web flags except modifications are done to an annotation called `raw-http` as well.

@mdeuser, currently the backend will delete all existing annotations whenever annotations on an action are modified. If we automatically set web action annotations to `false` whenever a call to `action update` is made without `--raw|--web`, we will delete the existing annotations on an action.
@mdeuser, by having `--no-web|--no-raw` flags we allow users to update actions without having to specify their annotations every time.

I modified the commit yet again.  As it turns out, switching from 

```
if o is not None:
    process_output_lines = o.strip().split('\n')
    last_line = process_output_lines[-1]
    for line in process_output_lines[:-1]:
        sys.stdout.write('%s\n' % line)
else:
    last_line = '{}'
```
to
```
if o:
    ...
```
changes the behavior.  This is because stdout/stderr (`o` and `e`) would NEVER be `None`, and `last_line` would ALWAYS be set, even if just to an empty string.  The `else` block NEVER got called.

In the failing swift3action test [above](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1867#issuecomment-286529111), `o` would be empty, and thus, `last_line = '{}'`, but `e` would have the stderr output from the failed action.  

The logic for checking if the action failed depends on whether `last_line` is valid JSON, NOT on the content of stdout/stderr, or on the return code from the subprocess.  In the future, I wonder if this should change, but for now, I'm simply removing the conditional check `if o...` to get back to the original behavior.
Instead of `--web (yes|true)|raw|(no|false)`, how about `--web none|raw|default` ?

Actions by definition must return an JSON object - it is incorrect to return anything else. 
Your action may appear to return a JSON array (or any legal JSON value) if you use a web action, e.g., to return `{ body: []}` instead.

I don't see us relaxing this restriction otherwise - it's fundamentally part of the action definition (dictionary in, dictionary out) and permits action composition.
a use case: if i have a rule that points to a sequence and one of the actions in that sequence does not exist, i get a silent failure. rule success! but no sequence failure activation record

`http://192.168.33.13` should be `http://192.168.33.13:10001` - the nginx conf (as you found) doesn't listen to port 80.
We've debated this in the past: should nginx support http as well; if we enable this but don't test it, it will break. If we enable it and test it, how much test coverage do we apply?

Ah, so the PR is wrong then, I added nginx listening on 80 so that everything was still going through there. So all the requests should be the same to the downstream systems.

Directly hitting the controller would change things much more.

Currently, it seems scanCode (and may of our tools) are assumed to work and not aware any have negative tests.  If there is a path/example to follow I am happy to do so, but my hope is to provide equivalent function, but make it config. file driven to allow flex. and prevent the need for code changes (.py).

Update on the journey getting Open Whisk to major on Python 3 and minor on Python 2...

~#1867~ solved most of the problems and ~#2044~ demonstrated the solutions to the remaining ones.

The checklist (in rough order of execution) now looks like this:
- [x] #2015 (approved)
- [x] #2047 Python 3 syntax errors in a pull request will fast fail the Travis build in the first minute.
- [ ] PR **TBD** to establish kind: Python (defaults to Python 3), kind: Python:3, kind: Python:2
- [ ]  #1903 Our go live on Python 3 PR

This branch has a conflict despite what github says (on the first commit when attempting to rebase). @cclauss do you mind rebasing this to upstream/master?
Fixes adopted by @cclauss in related prs.

[scanCode.py#L191](https://github.com/mrutkows/openwhisk/blob/96984a75db1fa3f18fa2a92ab4f0ca5e91506a8f/tools/build/scanCode.py#L191) and [scanCode.py#L238](https://github.com/mrutkows/openwhisk/blob/96984a75db1fa3f18fa2a92ab4f0ca5e91506a8f/tools/build/scanCode.py#L238) are Python 3 syntax errors.  Please consider changing `except Exception, e:` to `except Exception as e:` in these two locations to be compatible with both Python 2 and Python 3.  http://python-future.org/compatible_idioms.html#catching-exceptions  Once #2047 lands, these issues would halt the build on a pull request but before that happens, we need remain on the lookout.

It would also be advisable to avoid bare exceptions (L149, L151, L191, L238, and L322) where possible to avoid the pitfalls discussed in https://realpython.com/blog/python/the-most-diabolical-python-antipattern/  (Ignore the hyperbole of the opening paragraph)
